reviewText:
''Outlast contains intense violence, gore, graphic sexual content, and strong language. Please enjoy''
-Quoted from the game before you start playing Outlast.

As quoted here, this is exactly what Outlast is all about and is extremely well done, Especially the camera since you play as Miles Upshur, an investigative reporter whose ambition earn him an intimate tour of hell on earth. You start of as Miles driving towards the Mount Massive Asylum to uncover the secrets while you investigate the place that no other reporters would dare to do.

And since your only options are to proceed forward and uncovering the truth you either run, hide, or you die.

There will be a lot of unexpected things happening to you and the controls are very smooth, Especially while you use the camera, The battery only gets drained when you use the night vision that has a green view to it, and isn't very strong you can see a few meters ahead and should you run out of battery you will almost be completely blind adding a lot of tension to not consuming all of your batteries.

Navigating in the corridors of the Asylum, you're terrified of what awaits you and what as you uncover more of what has happened and is still happening, The secrets you find out that you never imagined was possible and as you're stuck in the Asylum trying to escape from the place. The language in this game surprises you kinda as it intesifies the experience in the game, It feels so real as if you were there.

In short, I really do recomend playing Outlast for those that enjoy playing horror games on evenings in the right atmosphere with a good headset so you hear well aswell.

Great game, 10/10, I couldn't have asked for anything better in Outlast.

reviewText:
Bar-none, THE greatest horror-genre game I have ever had the pleasure of playing.

This game had not only the horrific characters, but it also had an absolutely spectacular ambience to the entire game. The whole world just gives off this ominous feeling and you are unable to shake it throughout the entire game. If there is one game that I would HIGHLY recommend to anyone, whether you're a fan of horror-games or not, it would be this game. This game will ruin all other games for you and I am hoping that Amnesia: A Machine for Pigs (which is due for release in a few days), can duplicate the standard that this game just set for me for horror games, if not heighten that standard. I applaud Red Barrel Studios for this amazing work of art.

This has renewed my faith in the Horror Genre of video games.

UPDATE:

So I have decided to update this for the DLC that just came out, Whistleblower.  Whistleblower overall was a good game and followed suit with the original Outlast feel and atmosphere (which is a good thing!).  It did however become repetitive in its nature and being able to consistantly run-away from the enemies (and know you can without being caught) really began to dull the game experience and take the 'scare' out of it.  I wil say that I thoroughly enjoyed the new enemies and the freaky environment jump-scares.

Overall, up to the point of the DLC Whistleblower, I would give this game a 3-3.5 out of 5.  I feel that the game becomes too predictable after a certain amount of time and doesnt really push the importance of batteries onto the protagonist.  You can take pretty much all the time you want in the world and study the enemies patterns which makes it a lot easier/less scary.  I am hoping that the next DLC proves to be more unpredictable but I absolutely LOVED the ambience that was introduced during Whistleblower.

reviewText:
Possibly the scariest game I've EVER played. Outlast, which is a journey through an insane asylum that has become a true hell on earth, is Red Barrels' pride and joy, if you want my opinion on it. If you haven't played the game, allow me to explain how its scare factor is significantly high.

Similar to games like Amnesia and SCP: Containment Breach, Outlast is a survival-horror game where you only have three options, which (as stated in the intro of the game) are as follows: run, hide, or die. While this may make Outlast seem like a sort of ripoff, there are a few major differences, the greatest being the camcorder and how it is implemented into the gameplay. Not only is the camcorder your only means of navigating the dark via infrared vision, it also gives you the ability to get info on what happened in the story by recording certain events as they happen before you. This, to me, makes Outlast stand out to the other horror games I have played.

While the game does tend to get rather repetitive at some points, what with a find a few things while avoiding homicidal enemies in the process, this is only a minor flaw that can be overlooked if you try hard enough. Story, setting, ambience, and quite a few other things make this game feel like what a found footage film should aspire to be.

What really sells this game to me are the enemies themselves. Known as the Variants
date: the enemies of this game come in all shapes and sizes, quite literally. The unique Variants are the most effective means of terrifying the player, and their backstories (explained via documents found as you go through the asylum) make them even more monstrous.\n\nIf you're into scaring the pants off of yourself this Halloween (or any time of the year, really), I suggest you get Outlast. And if you have a little extra coin, put it into the Whistleblower DLC, which adds in a completely new story that ties in to the main game almost perfectly! This game is the scariest I've ever played, and I'm certain it will scare the pants off of you as well.

reviewText: This game is amazing. You play as a reporter, who gets an email saying some dark things are happening in an insane asylum (why didn't the person who send the email just contact 4 stoners and a dog?), and you try to find out what happened. The gameplay is similar to Amnesia, where you can't fight back, leaving you to hide, or outrun your persuers. What I loved about this game is that it uses jumpscares correctly, because they happen to suprise you so your defenses would go down, rather than trying to scare you. The graphics are great, and it makes the game feel more 'alive'. The enemies are quite horrifying, and the ones that scared me the most were the twins and the doctor (I forgot his name), not because they jump out at you, but because what they do to you. I would recomend this game to avid horror fans, and I am personally astounded by the game, but I am a little dissapointed at the length of the game, lasting around 3 to 4 hours long if you don't try to find everything. Overall, I love this game, and I can't wait to get whistle blower.\n\n(Update) I have gotten whistleblower on sale, and boy is it horrifying! I was not as scared playing outlast because I was playing with my cousin, and whistleblower gives you more reasons to be afraid. The main character in whistleblower is Waylon Park, who is a computer engineer for the mental asylum, who tries to tell Miles (the main character in Outlsat) about the happenings in the asylum. Before Waylon could send the message, he is taken and experimented on, but escapes and tries to find a way out. I have not beaten the game, but the enemies are really unpredictable, and Whistleblower is a great addon to Outlast. ONLY PLAY IT AFTER YOU HAVE BEATEN OUTLAST, AS WHISTLE BLOWER HAS A LOT OF SPOILERS! I will add more to the review after I beat whistleblower.

reviewText:
Most people will play Outlast with the expectation that it terrifies them. They'll play it because a friend sent it as a cruel gift, or because they know it'll be hilarious for others to watch on YouTube. The appeal of fear is pretty obvious, but if you're like me, horror games are never all that frightening. Still, I find myself playing horror games from time-to-time to see if they excell in other areas.

In that respect, Outlast is an excellent game. Underneath all the frequent (and often unavoidable) jump-scares and prolific gore, Outlast is a game with expertly-crafted mechanics, an intriguing (if convoluted) story to tell, and stunning visuals. You'll find yourself legitimately curious about what secrets Mount Massive Asylum holds. Unlike most survival horror games, Outlast doesn't bog the player down with a tedious inventory system or intentionally-unresponsive mechanics. Instead, the player quickly and fluidly navigates a labyrinthine environment, using only a night-vision camera to help see in the dark.

If you're a fan of horror games, then you've already played this. But if you never bother with games that just focus on being scary, I recommend you still give this one a try. Not because Outlast will frighten you, but because it doesn't sacrifice gameplay in favor of cheap scares for the easily-spooked.

reviewText:
If you're looking for a good scare, Outlast is certainly the game for you. I cannot say enough good things about it. The atmosphere is phenomenal and extremely well put together. Paired with the music and sounds, it can't get any better.
As for the actual gameplay, Outlast needs a little thinking involved. You shouldn't expect for everything to be clearly marked for you. Outlast does, however, get a little repetitive - grab your three items to unlock this or fix that and you advance, all the while a monster patient is lurking around. It can get to feel a little repetitive, but if you're like me, you won't exactly notice. You'll be too busy trying to keep yourself alive and complete the objective. One downfall I did notice, besides the repetitveness, was the length. I've realized that most modern horror games aren't incredibly long, and this game follows the rest. I do wish there was more story to find, more gameplay, and a change in pace - i.e. reduce the repetiveness and try something different with the flow of the game, which is something we can hope for in Outlast 2.
Outlast was a terrifying experience for me. There are gruesome cutscenes, jumpscares, and chase scenes. The characters are certainly twisted individuals. You can almost feel the pain, fear, and adrenaline that rushes through Miles Upshur, the protagonist in the story. His emotions are very well conveyed to the player. Not only Miles's emotions, but the various patients' emotions, as well. Plot twists, unexpected events, perfectly conveyed emotion, and a fantastic story really add to the game's atmosphere.
This is a game I will recommend one hundred times over. Very fantastic game with great features. It can certainly send chills up your spine.

reviewText:
When I first saw Outlast, I was intrigued. In the midst of so many Slender clones and games full of cheap, ineffective jumpscares, I was craving a sense of depth with a horror game. I found that depth in Outlast.

Taking the role of an investigative journalist acting on an anonymous tip, I entered Mount Massive Asylum and soon found myself creeping slowly through the seemingly abandoned wards, straining for any sounds beyond my own footsteps, jumping at my own shadow. The game's atmosphere is the best I've ever experienced, bar none. It forgoes the cheap horror tradition of relying on screams and musical stings, and instead uses your entire environment - creaking floorboards, closing doors, lightning and thunder, even distant, ragged breathing - to set you on edge and keep you there the entire time.

The game is brilliantly rendered, with stunning visuals and graphic depictions that truly reinforce the feeling that you've just stepped into hell on earth. The effects of the game on the main character become more and more apparent, and you'll notice a few types of damage you sustain stay with you for the entire game. The broadness of the creativity I experienced in the multitude of different settings kept me guessing, and the changes in venue served to take me out of my comfort zone JUST when I thought I was beginning to calm down. The pacing was perfect.

Gameplay was astonishingly spot-on. No glitches or bugs, and I was delighted to find that the main character, Miles, has a bit of parkour ability. Somebody put Mirror's Edge in a horror game? My character actually has a chance at running? I've never experienced that before, and the feeling of having a slight chance to survive while skillfully vaulting desks, hopping up to catch a ledge, and hanging out a window to avoid a pursuer, makes the experience both more terrifying and exhilarating when you narrowly escape with your life. The game makes you think, and if you forget to look up, you will die.

The story was phenomenal. Mount Massive, even in the state of its decay, is a living, breathing thing. With characters such as Chris Walker, Rick Trager, Dr. Wernicke, the Twins, Father Martin, and the Walrider, I found myself morbidly curious about how they came to be, and was delighted to find many answers. The Notes and Documents system added a whole new dimension of depth that made many of these characters more than just the monster you run from." Learning about Chris Walker's origins

reviewText:
IT'S NICE.
You play as Miles Upshur, a detective, who has to explore and discover the dark secret of the Mount Massive Asylum.
You have a camcorder, some batteries and your note block.
It's simple - Get in. Find the dark secret. Get out - Alive.
But there are some problems...!SPOILER ALERT!
like dead soldiers, an insane big ex-soldier, a crazy doctor (with a REALLY big scissor), the insanes...and...the dark secret which prevent you from escaping out of the asylum!

Outlast is a really terrifying horror-game... with some problems. But first let's come to the positive arguments!

++ it's a really scary horror-game
++ it's unique
+ the story doesn't deserve an award - but it's ok
+ the control of the game is easy and smooth
++ the graphic is just  NICE ! - it looks really realistic
+ intense violence
hoursPlayed: and strong language - please enjoy"\n+ things to find in the game are memos
voteText:
notes and spare batteries to keep your cameras nightvision function going to see in the dark.
+ play it with a friend on a big screen => much more fun!

- 5 hours (and I'm not the best player...) isn't really long
- the enemies are everytime the same
- I was a bit confused sometimes (where I have to go...)
- !SPOILER! I didn't liked these paranormal thing - Walrider
- sometimes too much gore - which makes it unscary (in some moments)
- 18

It's midnight and I decide to play, about an hour later there's a knock at my door it's a police officer, he tells me that there has been a report of a women screaming and if I've heard anything, I say I've not heard anything knowing that it's likely my screams have been reported to the police, he leaves and I see him knocking on neighbours doors asking them if they have heard anything.

10/10 police will be back.

reviewText: For those who say it isn't scary or a good game, they are dead wrong. No it's not the scariest game ever but it has enough creepy moments and jump scares to make your first play through very exciting. There were a few moments where the jump scares were so good i actually tensed up and slid my keyboard off my desk by accident, which of course call for a good laugh after. The game has a good length story for the money at around 6 to 8 hours if you play at a pretty normal rate. The whistleblower dlc for this is honestly even creepier than the original game and several friends of mine agree. I loved the whole night vision on the camera to be able to find your way through the dark asylum and the graphics were very good. In all a great game to pickup

reviewText:
This is the greatest horror game I have ever played. Everything is just, wow... The antagonists are well made, everything is very well detailed, and I especially love how you can see your feet, chest, arms, etc all by looking down - it's by far the best first person camera view I have ever looked through :D
Whenever I play this game, I always find myself hiding in a locker, or having this game paused for like 20 minutes, because it's very, very scary.

If you have a PS4 I strongly suggest you purchase it on that console. The PS4 has more features (like the insane difficulty).

reviewText:
Outlast is a pretty good game with really nice visuals and unique story- I was actually paying attention to notes in this game. Asylum is modeled very nicely and its full of cool looking freaks and weirdos.
Bad things - game rely on jumpscares way too much. The tension is good but they jumpscares gets old really fast.
The monsters have really obvious patrol patterns and are pretty easy to figure out.
Tasks are repetitive - turn on two things and avoid the bad guy to progress.
But overall I enjoy my time in Outlast - it was tense and nerve wracking at times in a good way.

reviewText:
amazing  and terrifying game.  i normally dont scare easily.. scarey movies no big deal to me ill watch in the dark with sound turned up and not be scared.  this game on the other hand turns me into a terrified child who is scared of the dark tossed into a pitch black room.

if you scare easily chances are you are going to be buying a game that you will not be able to play for more than 10-60 minutes.  my buddy who told me about it basically said not only game scares you it is stressful. i got to say he was pretty spot on because once you believe something is going to happen soon or after something scarey happens you feel super stressed(atleast i do) after im in a safe spot i find myself just staring at the screen just waiting for myself to relax and then i either proceed further or go nope i had enough save quit maybe ill try again another time if i dare

if your into scarey games this is a must buy! I'm pretty certain i will reach a point where i exit the game and never ever touch it again due to be too frightened and/or stressed out over what may happen next. at the time of this review there is a bundle on humblebundle that includes this game!

reviewText: On paper Outlast sounds like a cliche title. You're a journalist going to a psychiatric hospital to expose all the evil stuff going around there, while ignorantly thinking that you'll stay untouched. However, the game grabs you from the very beginning of the story, constantly keeps you on the edge of your seat and most importantly, Outlast will scare your pants off. Are you brave enough to step into Mount Massive Asylum and expose the secrets hidden away?

reviewText: Outlast is the best first person horror game I have ever played. No other game can make the player feel so immersed into the game as Outlast can, it feels the same as going through real-world horror interactive plays. The game nails an amazing horror story, atmosphere, charaters, graphics and sound effects! I highly recommend this game for anyone who is looking for a thrill! Be sure to pick up the Whistleblower DLC for even more awesome thrills and also helps extend and tell the story from a different character.

reviewText: Like amnesia,this game is probably one of the best atmospheric horror games out there. Armed with only a camcorder,your tasked to explore the moira asylum,however things take a big turn when you discover that the asylum is not what it seems to be.The game starts out well,tells you how,when and where to hide whenever your spotted by the variants.Sad thing however is that in my opinion although it's a little scary,the variants aren't that intimidating.Once you realise you can slam doors in their face and easily hide under beds or cabinets,it soon becomes a game of hide-and-seek.Intense parts were still and always will be the *special* variants that chase after you. So yes,if your looking for a game that is suspensful,i'll recommend outlast.

reviewText:
If you've played Amnesia you're in for a treat. Outlast gives you the same paranoia as amnesia but also throws a lot of unexpected jump scares in your face to peak your paranoia. Very fun and scary game.

Even though you're in an asylum, the environment changes drastically depending on which part you're in. Most of the changes are destroyed walls, stairs, floors, and lots of guts and blood which give it a unique art" style for each room.

Not being able to fight doesn't mean that you won't see any violence. Be prepared to see people get their heads ripped off
recommended: and disemboweled. This game is not for the faint of heart (though it is fun to watch those who scare easy play this game!)\n\nI highly recommend this game. I don't get scared easily and this game makes me very uneasy and on edge the whole time I play."

reviewText:
“The kind of things a man cannot see without changing in some irreparable way.”

Outlast represents a great horror game with a captivating atmosphere from the moment you set foot onto Mount Massive Asylum. While your only means of defense are running, hiding or using the environment to your advantage, you will experience some creepy moments trying to avoid being seen by enemies.

The excellent sound and ambient tracks contribute heavily to the game’s atmosphere and are supplemented by a decent storyline, that makes you care for your character’s well-being. And the ending is disturbing yet strangely satisfying.

Under normal circumstances puzzles are used to give the player a moment to relax. This game has no puzzle section at all, which will put you under constant pressure to proceed without respite.

Fun fact: The DLC complements the main storyline and provides an insight into the background story.
--

My rating system consists of six categories in descending order of importance:

-	Atmosphere
-	Characters
-	Details
-	Puzzles
-	Story
-	Controls

Based on the performance each category will receive one of the following grading:

-	S-Rank: excellent
-	A-Rank: very good
-	B-Rank: solid
-	C-Rank: satisfactory
-	D-Rank: inferior

If the S-Rank is awarded, a quote from the game or personal comment will be added as a token of my respect (in brackets).
--

Atmosphere: S-Rank

(Like the harder I try to escape, the deeper I get. Dead men aren’t a surprise anymore. Suicide seems wise.)

Characters: S-Rank

(How to make Trager Juice. Step 1: squeeze.)

Details: S-Rank

(♥♥♥♥ this place. Seriously, just ♥♥♥♥ this place. Dying keeps moving lower on the list of the worst things that could happen to me here.)

Puzzles: not applicable

Story: A-Rank

Controls: A-Rank
--

To conquer all achievements of Outlast and its DLC, you will most likely spend around 12 hours. There are no multiplayer achievements.

A detailed achievement guide can be found on the link below (thanks to Sgt. Darian and Spectral Knight).

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=258547524

Achievement difficulty: 4 of 10

Common:
- Singleplayer [+1]

Special:
- Bowelwhistler [+1]
- Lunatic [+1]
- Pulitzer [+1]
--

Outlast (PC) – First-person adventure game
(Horror / Survival) – 2013

reviewText:
Outlast is a short horror experience developed by a small team of ex-Ubisoftians.
In this game you take control of Miles Upshur, a reporter who is assigned to investigate Mount Massive Asyl...whoa what?
Now, even though the plot feels a bit pretentious at first, it still holds its interest due to great characters who inhabit the asylum. The graphics feel really great for an indie title, and the sound design is impeccable, from excellent acting to Samuel Leflamme's intense strings playing.

How about the scares? The world has a surprisingly creepy and disturbing atmosphere, but it relies too much on jumpscares and gore, even though it has genuinely frightening moments. Outlast is filled with intense chases instead, with sometimes several madmen hunting you from almost every possible direction. This fills the game with great pacing, which sparingly lets you breathe for a moment as you run away from disgusting monstrosities. And it's still scarier than Machine for Pigs.

Outlast stumbles mainly on the repetitiviness and level design of the middle act, which confused me far more than it should have. As I stated earlier, this game is short, with my playthrough lasting approx. 5 hours. Devs have promised additional content though. Enemy encounters can also be easily predicted and their AI is as predictable. And they have big, wobbling ♥♥♥♥♥.

My final verdict is 8/10. (Special thanks to Kiiro for gifting me this game.)

reviewText:
Spent £14.99 on a game I'm too scared to play.

Amnesia got me pretty bad, but you eventually just start focussing on the puzzles and the monsters just become a hinderance.

THIS however, is one hell of an experience. I'd recommend watching a Let's Play or some form of 10 minute gameplay so you can see what the game's like, honestly I struggle to handle it for more than 20 minutes at a time.

So far however, I love it. The environments, the soundtrack, spooky noises and just an overall feeling of helplessness. I haven't been this scared since watching Poltergeist as a child and developing an eternal fear of dolls.

8/10 LITERALLY only deducted those points because I've been too scared to make any real progress.

reviewText:
It's almost like a modern day Dark Descent on crack, with far superior graphics and gameplay.

Bought with the whistleblower dlc and had an absolute blast! The game's horror elements are a mix between extreme gorey violence, and atmospheric terror. I was only really terrified a few times in certain areas, but exploring the Asylum from start to finish was so much more fun than I thought it would be, and the endings for both the regular game and dlc actually surprised me. Leaves room for what I hope will be a sequel.

The graphics are by far the best you will get in a horror title. The game looks beautiful and the atmosphere is top notch stuff. Sound is also top notch and adds a ton to the suspense.

graphics - 10/10
sound - 9/10
gameplay - 10/10
story - 7/10
fun factor - 9/10

If you are a fan of horror games and can handle a lot of suspense, this is a masterpiece that should be on the very top of your list.

reviewText:
Ok,after the amount of game I've played so far(I'm at the point where you find Father Martin in the admin block),and the gameplay I've seen,I can say that this is an amazing horror game.
Whether you're a gore-thirsty kind of person,want good scares,or both,this game has a bit of everything for every kind of horror fan
The musical score by Samuel Laflamme is amazing and probably one of the best soundtracks I have ever heard in a horror game.
The plot: There's an investigative independent journalist named Miles Upshur. After getting an email from an anonymous source(Waylon Park from Whistleblower),he is prompted to go into Mount Massive Asylum and uncover the truth behind Murkoff's intentions in the asylum. He then finds that Mount Massive has a darker story behind it than it may seem.
The gameplay is great,with it involving carrying a camera around. This camera is important throughout the game because the camera has night vision that you can use to navigate dark areas.
The characters are great,have good voice acting,and are effective in scaring you(especially your first time playing).
In addition if you like the main story,there's DLC to the game,titled Whistleblower,and that expansion is as good as Outlast and is an amazing game as well :)

Overall this an amazing horror game that I recommend to everyone. 10/10 from me :)
(UPDATE July 12,2014 6:00 PM: just beat the game my first time,on to Whistleblower :) )
(UPDATE August 31,2014 2:04 PM: just beat Whistleblower,and I honestly have to say both are amazing horror games,and probably my favorite game on Steam :) )
(UPDATE Jan 19,2015 6:14 PM: Just got sub 10 on Any%(9:59.78) :D)
(UPDATE Feb 14,2015 5:47 PM: Speedrunning this game is ♥♥♥♥ing addicting)

reviewText:
Ok,after the amount of game I've played so far(I'm at the point where you find Father Martin in the admin block),and the gameplay I've seen,I can say that this is an amazing horror game.
Whether you're a gore-thirsty kind of person,want good scares,or both,this game has a bit of everything for every kind of horror fan
The musical score by Samuel Laflamme is amazing and probably one of the best soundtracks I have ever heard in a horror game.
The plot: There's an investigative independent journalist named Miles Upshur. After getting an email from an anonymous source(Waylon Park from Whistleblower),he is prompted to go into Mount Massive Asylum and uncover the truth behind Murkoff's intentions in the asylum. He then finds that Mount Massive has a darker story behind it than it may seem.
The gameplay is great,with it involving carrying a camera around. This camera is important throughout the game because the camera has night vision that you can use to navigate dark areas.
The characters are great,have good voice acting,and are effective in scaring you(especially your first time playing).
In addition if you like the main story,there's DLC to the game,titled Whistleblower,and that expansion is as good as Outlast and is an amazing game as well :)

Overall this an amazing horror game that I recommend to everyone. 10/10 from me :)
(UPDATE July 12,2014 6:00 PM: just beat the game my first time,on to Whistleblower :) )
(UPDATE August 31,2014 2:04 PM: just beat Whistleblower,and I honestly have to say both are amazing horror games,and probably my favorite game on Steam :) )
(UPDATE Jan 19,2015 6:14 PM: Just got sub 10 on Any%(9:59.78) :D)
(UPDATE Feb 14,2015 5:47 PM: Speedrunning this game is ♥♥♥♥ing addicting)

reviewText:
Outlast is a game that will make you afraid of the dark. Not only is it terrifying thanks to an utterly disturbing atmosphere, finely-crafted jumpscares (yes, it can be done) and a forboding musical score, it's also relentless and will never let you rest. Need a breather? Too bad, cos the psychopath behind you wants to wear your head like a hat, and he ain't gonna take no for an answer. You reckon you've been in a situation game-wise that made you feel completely helpless? Unless you've played Outlast, you don't know squat, pal.

Now some reckon that Outlast is a tad overrated, usually pointing out the flawed story and questioning why the protagonist doesn't simply leave the asylum. But honestly, in an era where every other horror game has either fallen victim to trends, turned themselves into an action-adventure game (looking at you, Resident Evil), or given up the ghost completely, this phenomenal game is a welcome return to decent, principled horror. Red Barrels (the development team) understands tension, atmosphere, and knows how to leave you beaten,  bloody, bruised, and begging for more.

It's a staggeringly beautiful, lovingly crafted and deliciously creepy game that has well earned the praise it has received. Any self-respecting horror fan will have this gem nestled among the rest of their collection.

reviewText:
In my opinion, the very best survival horror game of all time.

I have completed both the main game and Whistleblower DLC numerous times each and though they may seem like they don't have much replay value, it's like watching your favorite movie over and over; you know what's coming, but you still have a blast while watching (or in this case, playing).

If you are a fan of the horror genre, then get this game. If you are not a fan of the horror genre, do not ask if the game is scary or not. Even though it is a matter of preference what exactly you find scary, this game is definetly scary. It's got suspensful chase scenes, jump scares, and just plain general creepy-ness.

BUT

This game is not only scary, but it also has a very intriguing storyline as well. Both the main game and DLC are linked together, and you will discover more about the universe within the game in Whistleblower.

Though Whistleblower is a prequel (without giving away too much) towards the end of the DLC, the timeline syncs up with the main game and you see some of your actions unfold from the main game.

Also Samuel Laflamme has done a magnificent job with the score to this game. It's an eerie mix of creepy and beautiful, which really adds a whole new level of immersion to the game.

All in all this is a fantastic game, and is definetly worth full price.

reviewText:
It took me months to get to the end of this game, not because the game is difficult but it's because is the scariest game I've ever played. If you are looking to go into a horror trip make sure to get this game, it will definitely frighten you from the start. The feeling of confinement, despair and madness all over the place will make you enjoy the game fully if you're a horror fan.

I have to point this out, after playing the game for a while you get used to it and it's not as scary as it was in the beggining, also it gets repetitive and somewhat you can guess what's coming next in some parts.

The ambience, music and graphics are well designed and it trully adds a lot to the game.

Overall, this is a must have game that every horror fan should get.

9/10 for Outlast!

reviewText:
I'd consider Outlast to be way more of a thriller game with jump scares, than a horror game.

There's usually a point in these kinds of games where the scare tactics fade away, and you notice the mechanics behind them. Once that occurs, the game suddenly has a lot less tension, since instead of being super afraid of the monster pursuing you, you're now just paying attention to their looping routine around the level.

That happened within the first 20 minutes of Outlast for me. It's not necessarily a terrible thing, but it did remove a lot of tension from the game from that point on. It continued to degrade from there, as you find out that dying is often more advantageous than hiding, as it gets you to the starting point in the many Go find three Fuses/Turn two cranks/Pull two lever" 'puzzles' the game throws at you. When caught
date: you get a very clear look at a 3D rendered generic looking monster
recommended: which tears away any remaining fear of them. The sound design does a pretty good job at trying to restore some of it
hoursPlayed: and the chase sequences remained pretty okay because of that alone.\n\nThe thing that made games like Amnesia really special to me
voteText: is the looming sense of dread. Outlast never really had that for me. The nightvision camera effects were cool though
helpfulPercent: and the game does have it's moments of legitimate spooks. It's just more often than not
votesHelpful: you're left with a bad stealth game
votesTotal: with increasingly ineffective jump scares.\n\nI'll still probably check out the DLC
votesFunny: since I liked the game well enough. I just wished that the spooks lasted longer than they did."

reviewText: Outlast...\n\nSeriously, i gotta say, never has a game scared me the most since Amnesia: The dark descent, and hell that compared to Outlast is like a children game ! reviewText:
Outlast is a relatively well done survival-horror game which efficiently blends the thrills and chills in equal measure. However, while Outlast delivers an effective experience with the genre norm, it doesn't deviate from the set path for anything creative and unique. One can expect the usual set pieces, the usual enemies, and the overly used jump scares.

Now, to be fair... I certainly had my fair share of scares throughout the game (most of which were creatively placed), but towards adventures end I had found myself becoming slightly frustrated and annoyed with the lack of creativity. It was the same set path, over and over. Find this, hide from one enemy, run away, repeat. Outlast's biggest issue is the lack of enemy unpredictability, as essentially every encounter is scripted and therefore predictable.

That aside, Outlast is an extremely polished video game. The visuals are gorgous, realistic, and smooth. The audio is clear, crisp, and efficient at setting the mood. The use of the video recorder as night vision isn't anything new (and was a tad over-used), but was implemented and designed extremely well, and was definitely one of the games strongest aspects. Unfortunately Outlast is a short game, with limited (if at all), replayability.

I would only recommend a purchase of the game if it is on sale and you're itching for a quick horror fix.

reviewText: Short game, expect to beat it on your first playthrough in 5-8 hrs. Despite being a short game, the atmosphere is presented well. The night vision in your camera view made for an interesting aesthetic, abandoning the typical flashlight gear presented in a lot of horror games. While the game remains very playable on the first playthrough, the thrills and scares become boring and expected since there is not a variety of enemies. The documents are also a problem as they are many times dull to read, giving the player less incentive to seek out documents hiden throughout the asylum. Overall, playable game and worthy to add to your horror collection. 7/10

reviewText:
Was kinda reluctant to pick this up in the wake of the Slenderman horror crap flood but turns out Amnesia Dark Descent might have a competitor.

Id definitely rate the actual gameplay way weaker than Amnesia. Theres no fighting, only running like Amnesia but you only can hide in preset locations like lockers or by cowering behind objects. Added to that is alot of trial and error where you come into a new area and immediately dudes start chasing you so you bumble around and then die a few times until you figure out where to go and how to get there unscathed (or maybe its just me?). In Amnesia you could compensate much more easily for ♥♥♥♥ups and explore more easier since pretty much every shadow was a place to hide. Makes this game feel alot more static in comparision.

Theres bosses of some sort and i wish the game woulda kept to them for chasing you around or at least make the standard mooks disposable because seriously, after the umpteenth one those arent really scary anymore and id rather wander around looking at giblets sprayed on the walls or wondering if a corpse is only faking it instead of slamming face first into walls because i gotta run from some dorky freak with a piece of wood again.

Also the night vision camcorder is a neat idea and graphical effect with an interesting impact on gameplay - as long as you get to use it sporadically. Unfortunately it gets very very overused in particular towards the latter third of the game. After an hour of having green burn into my retinas those sections of the game became a ♥♥♥♥ing annoyance rather than scary. The game made up for it with a maybe clicheed but nevertheless refreshingly different endgame section tho.

So why am i recommending this despite trite gameplay and the developers being too lazy to do the lighting for a level or two or three? Because of the atmosphere. Great graphics, great music, the levels are diverse enough for being all in an asylum setting, the jumpscares are spot on and not too many and its also deliciously grody. Stinky corpse piles for the whole family!

reviewText:
Public Review on behalf of the Opium Pulses Steam group
Few words about the game
Outlast is a first-person horror game, created by an indie developers team. In game, you're in control of a journalist that came to an asylum to find out if those terrifying rumors he got from his source are real. Belive me, you're not ready for what is waiting inside...

Advantages
Immersive story with ton of surprising twists and turns
Every second of gameplay is full of tension
Realistic graphics along with frightening level design are making quite an awesome impression
Hide&Seek, along with parkour and sneaking elements creates one of a kind atmosphere
The AI of your stalkers in incredibly intelligent, it's quite scary when something walks by the bed you're hiding under, but it's horrifying when something is looking for you under every bed and in every locker
Sounds are simply stunning, they're more real than most of the things I hear on my daily basis
Files and recording provide an amazing backstory
Game is very intuitive, without any clear directions you are able to find your way to the objective
Disadvantages
Enemies get repetitive after a while
Summary
It's easily the best horror game I have ever played in my whole life and I think it will take a while until any new game will live up to this name. It's frightening and atmospheric, the story is deep and really interesting. Control over character is perfect, movement is great thanks to nicely done head bob effect and parkour elements. About that camera thingy... At first I was disappointed that it was a thing in game, but it was implemented perfectly, especially with night vision required to pass few levels. Everything just fits ideally and together creates Outlast, THE BEST horror game I have played and one of my favourite games overall.

Personal score
10 / 10
If you find my review helpful or funny be sure to follow Opium Pulses curator page right here for more reviewed games!

reviewText:
Simply nightmarish and surreal atomosphere. The last place I'd want to be stuck in is a mental asylum, on the top of a mountain, with little to no cell phone service. The enemies in this game are needless to say, bone-chilling, with evil backstory to reinforce their malevolent history and behavior. Personally, I believe the constant feeling of danger from some sort of sneak attack, or simply just shaking in my seat hoping that the enemy doesn't check my hiding spot is what truly gives this game the thriller that it so obviously portrays.

The atmosphere is extremely terrifying; it's as if danger is around every corner. You can't go anywhere without some kind of surprise, but they're all different so it's unique, you get scared everytime. The little things are very impressive too, like the night vision. It's not a very common idea, but the night vision is actually very effective at adding a creepy atmosphere, which the game doesn't really need; it's overkill. The fact that you can't just hide in the dark is also very giving to the atmosphere. There's 3 basic actions you can perform whenever a monster spawns: you hide, you run, or you die. I also enjoyed the even smaller things, like whenever you lean to peek through a doorway, your hand will show as in keeping structure and balance to your character; it adds realistic human body reactions, if you peered through a hallway at that much of an angle, more than likely you'll topple over.

The mechanics and controls of the game are flawless, to say the least. The fact that you can turn around to view your pursuer while you sprint for your life is surprisingly well done. My only real concern is the vaulting in the game. Let's say for example, you're being pursued by the ruthless Chris Walker, and a small desktop happens to block your hallway. Instead of your character vaulting it, he will jump right into the desk, hindering your movement, allowing your pursuer to get closer, putting you at risk. It all works out, nonetheless, because this adds psychological terror; personally, I think of it as: you know you messed up, and you're at a much larger risk of getting caught.

All in all
recommended: due to it getting kind of repetitive torwards the last little bit of the game. If you don't already own it
hoursPlayed: I'd recommend putting down a quick $20 to enjoy a one of a kind horror survival."

reviewText:
It's uncommon for someone to finish a game in one sitting. However, this is one of those games. Yes, this game is somewhat average in length, 5-6 odd hours, however I believe it is the the most atmospheric game of 2013, after Metro: LL. You play as a journalist who goes to an insane asylum somewhere in Colorado with nothing but your camcorder and a handful of batteries to investigate allegations of torture and other misuses of inmates. 10 minutes in and you fight for your life. The only supplies that you scavenge are batteries. If use your camcorder as well as its night vision your battery will drain twice as fast.

This game combines the best elements of Penumbra, Call of Cthulhu, Amnesia and forges a whole different monster of a game. The voice acting is outstanding, the level design is impeccable, the level of gore and nudity is unparalleled. This game does not attempt to scare you with cheap scares, it succeeds in terrifying you. There is necrophilia, torture, beheading, impalement, hanging, disemboweling, you name it - Steven King would stain his pants if he played this.

The graphics are outstanding. Especially the realistic furniture design coupled with rich textures - a remarkable feat with the Unreal Engine.

The gameplay: very few games from a first person perspective nail the concept of playing as a human, and in this game it FEELS like you are playing as a human in every sense of that concept. First off, you see your legs and you cast a shadow, THANK YOU. You cannot punch or kick, you are practically defenseless, you can climb up, climb down, you can crawl, you can peek from the behind corners while holding the wall with your hand, you can look behind you when chased, you can jump just far enough to be able to get a hold of that ledge 2-3 yards in front of you, you can hide under the bed or inside the lockers or inside the stalls and you can lurk in the dark corners waiting for your foes to pass by, you can hear your character's heartbeat as well as his erratic breathing and scream from sheer horror or pain and you can be wounded, permanently... No other game was able to capture this amount of atmospheric survival tension.

Just when you think you grew enough balls to be able to withstand the next encounter the game proves you wrong, lest you are able to think quickly on your feet, discern boarded up doors from the unlocked ones and be able to run and not get cornered. When encountered by a brute, you get one freebie - a slight knock around. Second time you get caught - you die. Most asylum residents are docile and oblivious, some are frightened more than you are, some strut around with their junk hanging like they own the place, ready to punch you and gut you if necessary. When you play the game without dying for 30 or 40 minutes you truly feel that payoff - as if you yourself were able to avoid a brutal death and the game provides you plenty of opportunity to live long enough without reloading if you are patient and agile enough.

The game is hard but it is also fair. Stealth is essential, noise is death and your ears are just as important as your camcorder. You won't always be able to see your enemies, but you should be able to hear them approach. The game tries its best to differentiate between locations, puzzles and succeeds in doing so for the most part.

When hiding you sometimes have to guess which one of the hiding spots the enemy won't check out. Sometimes you get lucky and sometimes you don't, but it's always best to get the hiding spot as far away from the door as possible.

The only few things that stand out is that you cannot turn the music off, which, actually fits in pretty well and helps build up tension although I'd prefer total silence when it comes to these things. Your character is pretty much mute when it comes to dialogue. Also, I would add the option of playing the game with permadeath mode.

I am happy to be living in an age when these types of games can be made. This is the first time when I tried recording my reactions while playing this game much like those youtubers do with Amensia, Horror House 2, etc.

We don't get too many well-made horror survival games and this is definitely it.

reviewText: Outlast is a unique horror experience that most games don't offer. I played through the entire game before writing this review. I am a huge fan of the horror genre, and it is very hard to find a game that scares me. While this was an amazing game, it was not very scary. This may be different for other people, but there were probably about 10 jump scares, and there wasn't really any psychological horror in it. The game was atmospherically horrific however, because 75% of the game takes place in the dark. The enemies in it were decently scary, and what I enjoyed was that you can not fight back. I loved the graphics on this game, they had their own king of feel to them. The gameplay was okay, but it got very repetetive because you were constantly having to find two things while being hunted by an enemy. One of the cool things about the gameplay was the use of the camera, which has limited batteries and has a nightvision mode. Throughout the game you can find bonus documents and read about different psychopaths and such, which was a very cool collectible experience. The story in it was okay, it wasn't too story driven, but there was a story. The game is not at all like a Silent Hill, or any other game that just uses psychological horror. Difficulty wise, the game wasn't hard, however there were parts that I died in over and over. The game should take at least 6 hours to beat without a walkthrough, so it was decently long. Overall, Outlast is a great game to play and I highly reccomend it.\n8/10

reviewText: Outlast is a unique horror experience that most games don't offer. I played through the entire game before writing this review. I am a huge fan of the horror genre, and it is very hard to find a game that scares me. While this was an amazing game, it was not very scary. This may be different for other people, but there were probably about 10 jump scares, and there wasn't really any psychological horror in it. The game was atmospherically horrific however, because 75% of the game takes place in the dark. The enemies in it were decently scary, and what I enjoyed was that you can not fight back. I loved the graphics on this game, they had their own king of feel to them. The gameplay was okay, but it got very repetetive because you were constantly having to find two things while being hunted by an enemy. One of the cool things about the gameplay was the use of the camera, which has limited batteries and has a nightvision mode. Throughout the game you can find bonus documents and read about different psychopaths and such, which was a very cool collectible experience. The story in it was okay, it wasn't too story driven, but there was a story. The game is not at all like a Silent Hill, or any other game that just uses psychological horror. Difficulty wise, the game wasn't hard, however there were parts that I died in over and over. The game should take at least 6 hours to beat without a walkthrough, so it was decently long. Overall, Outlast is a great game to play and I highly reccomend it.\n8/10

reviewText:
Outlast is a first-person horror game set in the mysterious Mount Massive Asylum, allegedly abandoned. You play as an investigative journalist who recieved an email prompting you to go, well investigate. The game quickly throws you into the tense, grim atmosphere of the asylum, and is unforgiving in its presentation.

The game is quite gory, and with excellent graphical quality. Most horror games don't particularly frighten me, but Outlast managed a few jumpscares that really got my heart pounding. The atmospheric quality was also excpetionally scary. It is definitely a frightening game.

The gameplay is reflective of the character; he's a reporter, not a warrior. When trouble comes your way, you run and you hide. There is no combat. You do, however, have a camera which serves in place of the standard flashlight or lamp using nightvision. It's not perfect, but that only adds to the feeling of being trapped and helpless. There are sections of the game that follow a very tired pattern of Go turn two valves" or "Go pull three levers
date:
but they weren't enough to take away from the overall value of the game.

The story was not particularly amazing, though I did enjoy it quite a bit. As the game was story driven, it was enjoyable to find the various documents and reveal the past of the asylum and its inhabitants.

Lastly, I'd like to complain against steam for not tracking offline play times, making my playthroughs of the game reduced to 45 minutes according to my account. Oh well.

All things considered, it was an excellent game. It exceeded my expectations. I would absolutely recommend it.
helpfulPercent: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: (Strongly recommended)\n\nOutlast is a genuinely scary experience by benefit of its airtight controls and finely crafted world. Great steps have been taken to avoid this game holding a single note from beginning to end. There is enough variety in the environments and scares to elevate a fairly superficial story to the nearest this gamer has been to a first-person, interactive horror film. I cannot count the times I have been lured increasingly closer to the screen only to leap backward from it in surprise or revulsion. There's an undeniable beauty to the game's human carnage which is both mystifying and frightful. The cruelty on display between characters and also towards you, the player, sets up a sense of incredible dread, of putting one's back to a window or door, of entering a room. So many times I wondered if I should just run away or shut down in the corner and wait for death. The game is gripping and certainly perfect for playing in the dark with surround sound. I dare anybody to play on Occulus Rift.

reviewText:
Before I go forward, I need to start off with this:
I didn't like Amnesia much at all.
The story was interesting but the gameplay itself as well as the scare factor was, to me, very overhyped. The gameplay seemed very much minimal and out of body. The entire time I felt I was looking in, and was not much immersed at all. Add to that the scare factor was greatly exaggerated and well... I was left disappointed.
And then I bought Outlast.
While there are many things I love about this game, I do need to put out a few warnings:
This game is really gory. Not much for the squeamish at all.
This game becomes very intense. I had to break at points because I just got too freaked out, something that hasn't happened to me since being hounded down by Nemesis in RE3.
I'll start off with the immersion.
Even though you -know- you're another character, his background is left vague and the only true objective you have is survive”. In this sense
date: it really becomes easy for the player to integrate his or herself with the character. That YOU are being chased
recommended: that YOU are cramming yourself in a locker
hoursPlayed: breaths stuttering and heart pounding as the door to the room is broken in. It makes it a very real sensation. I suppose it also helps to see hands reaching out to interact with objects rather than them floating in midair as well.\nThe second thing is the environment.\nVery eerie

column17: random rise reach your ears

column20: masked by footsteps and creaking doors.\nIf you're a horror nut

reviewText: Here's the deal with this game. Everyone wants more when it comes to video games, but in a survival-horror game you want quality over quantity and Outlast hits that nail. I bought it while it was on sale and was worth every penny (I can garuntee the length of the game is not worth the off-sale price). The game is short and can be beat in less than 10 hours, but the scares last a lifetime. When researching this game DO NOT form an opinion on how short it is (comes with S-H turf after all). The graphics are wonderful and the scares quite satisfying. Plot constantly twists and turn (like your head if caught sometimes XD) and the story is very in-depth and addictive. All in all, i give this game an 8.5 of 10 for scares alone. I do recommend this game be bought if it goes on sale again but wouldn't pay normal price for it.

reviewText:
Amnesia popularised a relatively new sub-genre of horror game that focused, as horror really should, on being unable to confront your enemies and hoping that you'll never have to do so.  A wave of imitiators and screechy Youtube reaction videos followed as it became clear how cheap and easy this kind of thing could be to put together.

So there's been a lot of dross, in other words, but the occasional gem.  Outlast gets the formula entirely right.  You're unarmed, sure, but physically capable:  you can sprint, vault over desks, clamber into vents, jump over broken floors, and generally conduct yourself as a reasonably healthy person would if they were being pursued by a nutcase.  The game emphasises your physical presence, down to the shadows you cast in front of you and your hands gripping the edges of walls when you're near them.

Not the longest game around, but the right length for what it wants to do, it does admittedly wear out its bag of tricks a little before the end - you'll begin anticipating things rather than being surprised by them.  This is a very minor quibble, though, and is kind of inevitable with this sort of thing.

Genuinely unsettling and occasionally very scary, this is how this kind of thing should be done.

reviewText:
Oh my gooooood...

I have played a lot of scary games in the past. They sometimes gave me some creeps. The best horror game I have played in the past must have been Silent Hill 2 or 4. Those were the top for me... until this game came along.

What the hell... this game is so scary. You really get into this game. You really feel like you're really there. You don't even need a big screen TV to get into it.

In my opinion, they took the best from Amnesia: The Dark Descent (namely the part that you don't have a weapon and need to run and hide, I didn't think the rest of the game was all that great and scary though) and the best from the Silent Hill games where they could also create scary scenes without the use of cheap jump scares.

Indeed: there are some jump scares, but they are scarce. Most of the scares, you get from feeling so helpless and alone, trying to find your way out, really wanting this game to be over... too bad it's not over yet for me... still... must.......play........

reviewText:
If Outlast was my real-life experience, I'd be terrified.
This game is wonderful: great ambience, soundtrack, story, and gameplay. Character design for the special, important enemies was wonderful. The game was so well made in my opinion, that I would definitely reccomend it to anyone. However there is one key trait missing, and I might not be the only one who thinks this.
I wasn't scared. A few times, I got scared, but overall this game didn't send me away ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ my pants.
See, the reason for this is not because the game sucks or anything; it's just that isn't how I get scared.
That being said, jumpscares scare the ♥♥♥♥ out of me. I am an extremely jumpy person, however Outlast has very little of these. The courtyard scene was the scariest part of the whole game in my opinion . Outlast has a much more sinister horror that either:
I somehow am unphased.
am playing the game way wrong.The looming threat will not terrify me, unless he always knows where I am, throws a rock to distract me, and pops up behind me before I turn my head around again. A game like muh Slender has me ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ in fear because that kind of enemy is everywhere, and All-Knowing, and my heart can't take it. The enemies in Outlast are not; I played this through like a game of Hide and Seek. That is until I had no batteries, OR I lost my camera for a brief 5 minutes then the game got scary.

My griping over and done, buy this game and play it; it's a wonderous, well detailed game.
10/10 would outlast again

reviewText:
I got this game on sale a while ago and it sat in my inventory for quite some time without being played.

Well, when I clicked play that first time, it was amazing.

Normally I don't do the whole Singleplayer game, and I definitely don't play First Person Shooters without the all-important shooter
date:
but this game had me second-guessing my gaming platform.

This game got me about 5.5 hours of HORRIFYING gameplay.  I've never played a game that startled me into actually physically jumping.  Well-done.

This game is an auto-include to any Steam gamer's library.

It has lore (little notes and documents that are reminiscent of Resident Evil 1-3).
It has a horrific atmosphere (think lighting, setting, and music similar to Silent Hill 1-3).
At the end, it's most important element that makes it what it is, is its feeling of hopelessness.  This game even tells you that you have three options: Run, Hide, or Die.  There is no fighting back, and it's what drives the horror in this game.

If you're having second guesses, don't.  Buy this game.

reviewText:
Another horror game where you can only run and hide, Outlast doesn't do a whole lot that's new but it stands tall as a strong, polished game that's genuinely scary. Essentially Amnesia-style gameplay in a new setting, it's good-looking, well-designed and doesn't fall prey to many of the pitfalls that remove the horror from supposedly scary games - it knows when to use silence and emptiness to full effect and doesn't ramp up the action as the game progresses, barring the weak ending.

Jump scares come often and can get predictable, and aren't the main strength of the game. It's the organic horror that comes from being stalked or looking for a hiding spot in a panic that really makes it memorable. The sheer gore and disturbing elements, including sexual overtones to the antagonists, are uniquely unnerving though they might alienate some players. Good horror doesn't need to be gruesome, after all.

Fairly short and with a very weak final act much less compelling than the rest of the game, it's not for everyone, but is fine fuel for those who love the unmatched rush of feeling genuinely afraid.

reviewText:
Why would anyone in their right effing mind make a game like that.
Don't get me wrong, I like a good survival horror game. And you know what the favorite part for me in these games is?
It is that despite all the traps, despite the horde of zombies, necromorphs, aliens, mutants, degenerate inbred cannibalistic nuclear holocaust survivors those sick game developpers throw at you, their is always a time; that sweet sweet moment when you know you are utterly pooped; and one last time, you can turn around and empty every freaking clip of every freaking gun/slicer/flamethrower right in their freaking face.

Now
In this game, you can't do that.
Cause they don't give you no freaking gun.

You get a camera, so you can document your glorious end shivering in a closet, breathing heavily,until some insane mutated naked (yes) crazy dude finds you.
So I played 3 deadspaces in the dark. It was not always easy, but I did.
This one is just too much for me.

reviewText:
Solid survival horror game with some flaws. 7/10

PRO:

+ Dense atmosphere - the game will keep you on edge from start to finish.
+ Great musical score - very high production value here; the game sounds like a Hollywood movie.
+ Game mechanic - The camcorder feels fresh and new
+ Game mechanic - The chases are very well done

CONS:

+ Level design - Some of the dark passages are more annoying than scary when you can't see a thing even with the nightvision on.
+ Game design - The chases are getting repetitive after a while.
+ Short - You can finish this is about 6 hours. Limited replay value.

VERDICT:

Solid survival horror experience with some design flaws. I'd buy it when it goes on sale. If you like horror movies, Amnesia and the F. E. A. R. series (without guns) then you're going to enjoy this ride.

reviewText: A horror game without combat, without weapons, your defenses are to run, and hide. You won't feel scared for 20 minutes, and like a powerhouse for the rest of the game. You will run, you will scramble, you will slam doors shut behind you and with your heart rate ever increasing, try to shove a cart in the way to block the door. You will be scared.\n\nOutlast is intense, and scary, something very few games manage to do. It never feels too easy, or too difficult, and most importantly never feels cheap or gimmicky. In a nutshell, this is just an excellent horror game. It pulls in influences from a few stories, games, movies, and all fits together in a great, intense package. Definitely one to try out if you enjoy horror games.

reviewText:
I’m a huge fan of horror movies and games. Unfortunately, after Silent Hill’s 1-2-3-4, Forbidden Siren’s 1-2 and Resident Evil’s 1-2-3 there is not much games that can kick the s**t out of me (well, the SH: Homecoming did it, coz this game was so terrible that I was scared to death of what they did with Silent Hill… T_T ). Yeah, Amnesia was nice, but pretty poor executed, imho. I enjoyed it as P.J. Lovecraft fan, but that’s it.
And I should say now: “Outlast is GREAT!” I can’t say that it frightened me much (four jump-scares caught me thou), but it gave me really unique disturbing, sick and gore feeling of horror happening all around for the whole 4 hours of gameplay. Outlast is short, but I really don’t regret about money spent on this game. It’s very nice, dark, bloody and solid interactive story to enjoy with great atmosphere of damned asylum. If you’re a horror fan – you should play it, no doubts.
Yours,
V-Raptor

reviewText:
Amnesia popularised a relatively new sub-genre of horror game that focused, as horror really should, on being unable to confront your enemies and hoping that you'll never have to do so.  A wave of imitiators and screechy Youtube reaction videos followed as it became clear how cheap and easy this kind of thing could be to put together.

So there's been a lot of dross, in other words, but the occasional gem.  Outlast gets the formula entirely right.  You're unarmed, sure, but physically capable:  you can sprint, vault over desks, clamber into vents, jump over broken floors, and generally conduct yourself as a reasonably healthy person would if they were being pursued by a nutcase.  The game emphasises your physical presence, down to the shadows you cast in front of you and your hands gripping the edges of walls when you're near them.

Not the longest game around, but the right length for what it wants to do, it does admittedly wear out its bag of tricks a little before the end - you'll begin anticipating things rather than being surprised by them.  This is a very minor quibble, though, and is kind of inevitable with this sort of thing.

Genuinely unsettling and occasionally very scary, this is how this kind of thing should be done.

reviewText: Here's the deal with this game. Everyone wants more when it comes to video games, but in a survival-horror game you want quality over quantity and Outlast hits that nail. The game is short and can be beat in less than 10 hours, but the scares last a lifetime. When researching this game DO NOT form an opinion on how short it is (comes with S-H turf after all). The graphics are wonderful and the scares quite satisfying. Plot constantly twists and turn (like your head if caught sometimes XD) and the story is very in-depth and addictive. All in all, i give this game an 8.5 of 10 for scares alone. I do recommend this game be bought if it goes on sale again but wouldn't pay normal price for it.

reviewText:
Before I go forward, I need to start off with this:
I didn't like Amnesia much at all.
The story was interesting but the gameplay itself as well as the scare factor was, to me, very overhyped. The gameplay seemed very much minimal and out of body. The entire time I felt I was looking in, and was not much immersed at all. Add to that the scare factor was greatly exaggerated and well... I was left disappointed.
And then I bought Outlast.
While there are many things I love about this game, I do need to put out a few warnings:
This game is really gory. Not much for the squeamish at all.
This game becomes very intense. I had to break at points because I just got too freaked out, something that hasn't happened to me since being hounded down by Nemesis in RE3.
I'll start off with the immersion.
Even though you -know- you're another character, his background is left vague and the only true objective you have is survive”. In this sense

reviewText: Outlast is a great game and it really deserves the title of the scariest game of 2013. I really got scared many times in the game and after I really laughted at myself. The game really challenge you with dark areas and the way you react in a emergency moment when you see a lunatic in your front. The game has excellent graphics and I really loved the camera that we use and the night vision, it make it feel more scarier and I also thought that was really original. Althought the game is scary and you have a lot of fun, it also brings shocking scenes that contain violence. So before buying it, you need to be aware that you are not influenced on this type of violent game and neither believe in spirits or have some kind of disease that can influence your own life somehow like my first day playing I had nightmares. So really think to your self if you want this kind of entertainment for you.\nOther way, I finished the game 4 hours and I had the impression that this lasted forever. It is not long and you get stuck many times on corridors not knowing what you need to do or where you need to go. The own terror makes you scared to move forward and get out of the areas you are hidden. In the game you cant punch or attack your enemies just run from them and defend yourself when they jump on you. You can also hide in places such as beds, shelfs, behind desks and others. It's really interesting and different how they planned the game, while running from a lunatic you can also look behind to see if someone is folllowing you. Also you can close doors to hold the enemies and put objects over it so it get harder to they brake the door.\nYou can film everything that happens on the game but after you cant see what you filmed that this was kind of dissapointing but the gameplay in general is way better than any horror game I ever played before. I totally recommend this game for the more prepared people that are accustumed to play scary games. My only concern is the ending of the game that was a lot dissapointing, more than anything. I won't spoil anything but, yes, the ending is horrile and unbelievable. But not considering that, don't disseast from buying it, the price total worth it and the gameplay and the art of the game is cool.

reviewText:
Outlast is a first-person horror game set in the mysterious Mount Massive Asylum, allegedly abandoned. You play as an investigative journalist who recieved an email prompting you to go, well investigate. The game quickly throws you into the tense, grim atmosphere of the asylum, and is unforgiving in its presentation.

The game is quite gory, and with excellent graphical quality. Most horror games don't particularly frighten me, but Outlast managed a few jumpscares that really got my heart pounding. The atmospheric quality was also excpetionally scary. It is definitely a frightening game.

The gameplay is reflective of the character; he's a reporter, not a warrior. When trouble comes your way, you run and you hide. There is no combat. You do, however, have a camera which serves in place of the standard flashlight or lamp using nightvision. It's not perfect, but that only adds to the feeling of being trapped and helpless. There are sections of the game that follow a very tired pattern of Go turn two valves" or "Go pull three levers
date:
but they weren't enough to take away from the overall value of the game.

The story was not particularly amazing, though I did enjoy it quite a bit. As the game was story driven, it was enjoyable to find the various documents and reveal the past of the asylum and its inhabitants.

Lastly, I'd like to complain against steam for not tracking offline play times, making my playthroughs of the game reduced to 45 minutes according to my account. Oh well.

All things considered, it was an excellent game. It exceeded my expectations. I would absolutely recommend it.
helpfulPercent: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: (Strongly recommended)\n\nOutlast is a genuinely scary experience by benefit of its airtight controls and finely crafted world. Great steps have been taken to avoid this game holding a single note from beginning to end. There is enough variety in the environments and scares to elevate a fairly superficial story to the nearest this gamer has been to a first-person, interactive horror film. I cannot count the times I have been lured increasingly closer to the screen only to leap backward from it in surprise or revulsion. There's an undeniable beauty to the game's human carnage which is both mystifying and frightful. The cruelty on display between characters and also towards you, the player, sets up a sense of incredible dread, of putting one's back to a window or door, of entering a room. So many times I wondered if I should just run away or shut down in the corner and wait for death. The game is gripping and certainly perfect for playing in the dark with surround sound. I dare anybody to play on Occulus Rift.

reviewText:
Outlast, man where do I even start? Outlast is a decent psychological horror game. It had a strong beginning. But as I progressed throughout the game, it becomes a glorified Hide and Seek with Fetch Quests over 9000. Whatever scary ambience it might've had disappeared and left me frustrated as I encounter these annoying mooks that tend to get in my way when I just want to progress with the story. The Level Design can be so frustrating especially when landmarks look alike. You'll find yourself stuck in an hour on an area if you're not careful or can't remember where you went because you're too busy running away from the annoying predator.

A piece of advice, don't apply logic on Horror games, they don't work most of the time and you will tend to miss some vital areas. (e.g. Go into a room where it's all bloody and there are people in despite being an outsider, lol).

Do I want to recommend this? Yes and No. I like Outlast's ambience, voice acting and the setting. What I just hate about it is how the gameplay works. I have a Let's Play archive for the first 4 hours of the game over here if you're curious! http://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL6U27R6KU6-NadYp3dBUPK-wwKxVVoVw_

reviewText:
Outlast is a picture perfect example of everything done right in a horror game, making the player feel completely helpless and hunted in an environment that makes them feel uncomfortable with a looming sensation of something just around the corner. With 0% of the budget on combat, Outlast has been made completely immersive with subtle and frightening sound effects, disturbing visuals and perfected first-person animations.
The story of Outlast begins with a midnight drive to a supposedly abandoned asylum following a tip from an anonymous lead, the player takes the role of investigative journalist Miles Upshur as he delves to uncover the sinister secrets of Mount Massive Asylum.
Immediately upon entering the asylum the player gets a sensation of being watched, confined and exposed, setting them up for a start at the slightest bump, scratch or shed of movement seen from the corner of your eye. The atmosphere is perfected with high-quality graphics and sound assets, which build up in intensity until exploding in the players face in an intense climax of terror upon their first encounter with one of the asylums mutilated patients.
As with any game, while Outlast is good there are some drawbacks that keep it from being perfect. Outlast's puzzle solving lacks variation, recycling the same old method of rushing to press a button or turn a valve while an enemy chases you. While contributing to the sensation of being hunted, re-using these kinds of encounters over and over with a lack of effective follow-up made the game feel largely repetitive and I felt took a large part out of the experience.
Outlast has also unfortunatly indulged in the cheap shots that are jump scares, which require little-to-no buildup and I feel have no place in a true horror game as they only serve to provide opportunities for talentless hacks like pewdietard to overreact. In comparison with another terrifying game, Amnesia: The Dark Descent, which had no jump scares and instead relied completely on it's atmosphere to scare the player, this comparison proves to me that horror games worth their weight in gold do not need jump scares and should rely on their immersion, which is something that Outlast would have done very well.
Finally, without giving away too much, the story felt rushed and incomplete in some places, which didn't leave a lasting impression on me and failed to avidly explain the reasoning behind the inhumane experiments in Mount Massive.
So while Outlast is a very good game and a welcome addition to the horror genre, it suffered some flaws that kept it from living up to it's full potential.
Amnesia: The Dark Descent remains the scariest game I've played.

reviewText:
After the disappointing sequel to Amnesia, it was time to play a game that lives up to the genre Horror/Survival. Luckily there was Halloween sale on Steam and this game was put in the basket.

The game in a nutshell: you are a reporter with a hand camera as a deadly weapon. You want to investigate an asylum where supposedly experiments were performed on the nut jobs locked in there. Getting in is a piece of cake, but getting out, that's what the whole game is about.

The macabre atmosphere is overwhelming at start. You continuously look through the lens of you camera, because it is equipped with night vision. This green/black tones add to the darkness of your environment, making it easy to poop your pants whenever a freak comes dangling from the sealing or start chasing you in a hall way. But in the end, this scary stuff also loses its effect if you are being chased around for the umpteenth time and all you want is the chase to be over and continue.

Nonetheless, a great addition to the Horror/Survival genre and let's hope the Outlast 2, which is currently in the making, continues along this path.

Edit: just finished the Whistleblower DLC. Nice addition to the game, but nothing special. Look at it as a Blue Shift to Outlast.

7/10

reviewText:
Solid survival horror game with some flaws. 7/10

PRO:

+ Dense atmosphere - the game will keep you on edge from start to finish.
+ Great musical score - very high production value here; the game sounds like a Hollywood movie.
+ Game mechanic - The camcorder feels fresh and new
+ Game mechanic - The chases are very well done

CONS:

+ Level design - Some of the dark passages are more annoying than scary when you can't see a thing even with the nightvision on.
+ Game design - The chases are getting repetitive after a while.
+ Short - You can finish this is about 6 hours. Limited replay value.

VERDICT:

Solid survival horror experience with some design flaws. I'd buy it when it goes on sale. If you like horror movies, Amnesia and the F. E. A. R. series (without guns) then you're going to enjoy this ride.
