reviewText:
This game is absolutely everything you could ever want in a horror game; great atmospere, beautifully disturbing character design, brilliant attention to detail, and a storyline that will keep you guessing and completely terrified.
Outlast is such a perfect game in my opinion, despite occasional (extremely minor) glitches, and utilizes every bit of its strengths to successfully leave an impression on whoever plays it.

Pros:
-Successfully utilizes the occasional jumpscare, without doing it cheaply
-Great sounds=awesome atmosphere
-Immersion is easy; this game really messes with you psychologically!
-Situations that require strategy are believable, and not excessively difficult
-Tons of plot-twists!
-THE CAMERA MECHANIC!!! It's utilized, amazingly, in a very well-done and logical way!!!
-Every NPC is brilliantly detailed in design!

Cons:
-Several [minor] glitches
-Can cause a bit of lag on lower-end PCs
-The plot can seem a bit confusing at times
-Counts on a good ability to overcome fear in order to progress (Hard to play if you have low tolerance for horror)

All in all, if you want to play a great game that will take some decent time to finish, offers a challenge, and could possibly make you scream like a little girl, Outlast is definately the perfect game to try!! Definately worth the money, too! :)

reviewText: I came to enjoy this beautiful game; a skillful work of art to creep, hide or run in. Shades of 'Metal gear solid' and the early 'Thief' games with a clever eye for detailed mayhem, the creepiness of the place, the glaring lights (where applicable), the locked doors overlooking easy escapes, the tight places, the underlying sense of immenent and ever-present danger; ... the delapo-porn aspects of this game were quite refreshingly well conceived, 3 thumbs up to the devs.\nThe scares are well designed and engaging but the conceptualization of the game is a testimony to the breadth of the team's vision. The melding of challenging visuals, erm... enforced partial non-visual experiences and excellent audio work made for a slow-burning ramp of confidence and capability I have rarely felt in other games.\nThere were some neat tricks that didn't come off too well, the camera dropped"/totally helpless sequence lead to some great stuff but cues for gaining the full terror of the event could easily have been missed
date: the malevolence of the 'Twins' was fantastic but I would have liked to engage (i.e; Run screaming away from) with these guys more
voteText: the twins and the Walrider is incredibly confusing at face value and I believe may have suffered from the unsettling 'notes/documents' interface. The end scenario seemed a little confusing to drop on the player after all the skills acquired in the earlier sections but the dramatic change in tone brought a challenging edge of dilemma to strategy-making on-the-fly.\nFor fans of 70's horror movies and stealth-em-ups you can do way worse than have a shot at this title

reviewText:
Another horror game where you can only run and hide, Outlast doesn't do a whole lot that's new but it stands tall as a strong, polished game that's genuinely scary. Essentially Amnesia-style gameplay in a new setting, it's good-looking, well-designed and doesn't fall prey to many of the pitfalls that remove the horror from supposedly scary games - it knows when to use silence and emptiness to full effect and doesn't ramp up the action as the game progresses, barring the weak ending.

Jump scares come often and can get predictable, and aren't the main strength of the game. It's the organic horror that comes from being stalked or looking for a hiding spot in a panic that really makes it memorable. The sheer gore and disturbing elements, including sexual overtones to the antagonists, are uniquely unnerving though they might alienate some players. Good horror doesn't need to be gruesome, after all.

Fairly short and with a very weak final act much less compelling than the rest of the game, it's not for everyone, but is fine fuel for those who love the unmatched rush of feeling genuinely afraid.

reviewText:
I got this game on sale a while ago and it sat in my inventory for quite some time without being played.

Well, when I clicked play that first time, it was amazing.

Normally I don't do the whole Singleplayer game, and I definitely don't play First Person Shooters without the all-important shooter
date:
but this game had me second-guessing my gaming platform.

This game got me about 5.5 hours of HORRIFYING gameplay.  I've never played a game that startled me into actually physically jumping.  Well-done.

This game is an auto-include to any Steam gamer's library.

It has lore (little notes and documents that are reminiscent of Resident Evil 1-3).
It has a horrific atmosphere (think lighting, setting, and music similar to Silent Hill 1-3).
At the end, it's most important element that makes it what it is, is its feeling of hopelessness.  This game even tells you that you have three options: Run, Hide, or Die.  There is no fighting back, and it's what drives the horror in this game.

If you're having second guesses, don't.  Buy this game.

reviewText:
Oh my gooooood...

I have played a lot of scary games in the past. They sometimes gave me some creeps. The best horror game I have played in the past must have been Silent Hill 2 or 4. Those were the top for me... until this game came along.

What the hell... this game is so scary. You really get into this game. You really feel like you're really there. You don't even need a big screen TV to get into it.

In my opinion, they took the best from Amnesia: The Dark Descent (namely the part that you don't have a weapon and need to run and hide, I didn't think the rest of the game was all that great and scary though) and the best from the Silent Hill games where they could also create scary scenes without the use of cheap jump scares.

Indeed: there are some jump scares, but they are scarce. Most of the scares, you get from feeling so helpless and alone, trying to find your way out, really wanting this game to be over... too bad it's not over yet for me... still... must.......play........

reviewText:
If Outlast was my real-life experience, I'd be terrified.
This game is wonderful: great ambience, soundtrack, story, and gameplay. Character design for the special, important enemies was wonderful. The game was so well made in my opinion, that I would definitely reccomend it to anyone. However there is one key trait missing, and I might not be the only one who thinks this.
I wasn't scared. A few times, I got scared, but overall this game didn't send me away ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ my pants.
See, the reason for this is not because the game sucks or anything; it's just that isn't how I get scared.
That being said, jumpscares scare the ♥♥♥♥ out of me. I am an extremely jumpy person, however Outlast has very little of these. The courtyard scene was the scariest part of the whole game in my opinion . Outlast has a much more sinister horror that either:
I somehow am unphased.
am playing the game way wrong.The looming threat will not terrify me, unless he always knows where I am, throws a rock to distract me, and pops up behind me before I turn my head around again. A game like muh Slender has me ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ in fear because that kind of enemy is everywhere, and All-Knowing, and my heart can't take it. The enemies in Outlast are not; I played this through like a game of Hide and Seek. That is until I had no batteries, OR I lost my camera for a brief 5 minutes then the game got scary.

My griping over and done, buy this game and play it; it's a wonderous, well detailed game.
10/10 would outlast again

reviewText: Outlast is one of the scariest games I have ever played, and yes I would say it is scarier than Amnesia. The reason why it is effective is so obvious that I'm surprised more games don't do it. Here is the secret ladies and gentlemen. PACING. Yes, it truly boggles the mind, but PACING is the key to a good survival horror game. The game doesn't just start throwing you into an attack from a murderous zombie army with a shotgun in one hand and your ♥♥♥♥ in the other. You start reading about a strange facility, you travel there in your car, and enter it. Even after that you aren't attacked for about a half hour. Now, keep this in mind. The game does occasionally use jumpscares, but honestly I don't mind them. They are used sparingly and the scariest part is the anticipation of the jumpscare. They are only used about 3 times throughout the story. Now, I'm not going to spoil the story, so there won't be a breakdown on what I do and do not like about the story, but it is told fairly well through documents and notes found throughout the facility. Overall, I'd give the game about a 9/10.

Okay, I didn't go in blind. I've seen a gazillion Let's Play videos on YouTube before playing this on my Xbox. I've gotten this game three hours ago and finished it five minutes ago (not counting the DLC).

Why?
The chases.

Sure, it's just the chases that still got me, but it does have a replay value (to me, at least), and the story is still very interesting.
Can't wait for Outlast 2!

reviewText: Outlast puts most recent horror" games to shame.\n\nTaking a leaf from games like Amnesia
date: Outlast puts us in the shoes of Miles Upshur; an investigative journalist who sneaks into Mount Massive Asylum after a tip mentions the horrific excperiments conducted inside the walls. He'll soon learn to regret entering this place of sheer and utter nightmare fuel; as the game becomes a desperate fight for survival and a dash for the exit.\n\nOutlast visually represents a Triple A title
recommended: with the minds of them behind the making; but its gameplay is similar to it's indie counterparts where combat is not an option. The game requires exploration
hoursPlayed: investigation that rewards us with further exposition of what is truly going on; aswell as more batteries for the camera you carry that is the only source of seeing in the pitch black hallways.\n\nWhether it's finding fuses
voteText: navigating vents or hiding from naked dudes with pipes; the game is a truly terrifying and polished experience; any issues such as a short length of about 7-9 hours and an abrupt ending; are for the most part shadowed by the exilirating thrill this game offers by combing  the best of the gaming worlds.\n\nOutlast raises the bar for every future horror game
helpfulPercent: indie or not. The developers are also talking about making the sequel ;)\n\n4/5"

reviewText:
For the scare factor of this game, it's wonderful with the graphics, sounds, and all around atmosphere. I would have to say I thoroughly enjoy playing the game, although I will say some of the mechanics do get a little tedious(run turn on this thing, avoid getting caught, batteries, though I never ran out,) and the logic of the character you play is questionable, regardless I still enjoyed the experience.

I personally think finding the documents does aid in learning the story behind the asylum, and a nice challenge to give yourself to find them, I'm pretty sure I missed a few, but how many you get doesn't effect anything in the game really.

There is a certain point during gameplay where things don't necessarily scare you as much, but rather you get that adrenaline rush and thrill of hiding and evading whatever threat there is to you, similar to the thrill of hide and seek, or tag.
Also it's designed to creep you out, or make you a little sick rather than scared.

I definitely recommend playing it alone and in the dark, with the fewest distractions possible.


If you speed run this game you can do it probably 6 hours first time and less, subsequent times.
I took 10 hours overall my first time, including deaths and occasionally getting stuck stupidly.
I personally think this game is worth the price, I did get it on sale for $7 I think, though the $20 makes sense because not every game can be cheap.

reviewText: Be ready to ♥♥♥♥ your pants, a lot. Outlast is a survival horror game where you CANNOT fight back. This means your ways of surviving are to run, and hide or not get seen at all. It gives you the feeling of terror to know you're helpless once you get found. Now I played only on the normal difficulty but I imagine the harder the difficulty the less batteries for your camcorder AKA your source of light in the dark are spread around. Now minus that I did come to a part where I had no batteries and I could barely see anything at all, I nearly ♥♥♥♥♥♥ my pants and shut the game off. Other than that there are some scenes with full out nudity, thank Gods for the terrible lighting or I would have saw what hangs between my legs. Now overall Outlast is a great game, it lacks a large soundtrack but the silence can be scary at times. Depending on how brave, fast and smart you are this game can last anywhere from 4 to 12 hours in gameplay.  Now a big issue with this game like all ones it the main kinds of times you get scared are from scripted jump scares, like all Horror games these happen sadly. As I remember there are only a handful of the scripted ones but the hunting" parts of the game are horrid. (Horrid in a good way.)  The hunting sequences are when an AI (Weather a standard enemy or a "boss") is in the area where you need to solve a puzzel or get a key etc. etc. patrols around looking for you usually in the pitch black. Overall the game is great for it's time and deserves a 9/10 and a ♥♥♥♥ your pants seal of approval."

Anywas, this reminded me of Amnesia: The Dark Descent.  The atmosphere will make you wary, and fairly queasy as well.
I'm no horror pro player, but I do love them. Id say a quarter of my 42 minutes was spent constantly peeking into hallways, terrified to go down it, because a damn door will slam right next to you, and you'll discover to your dismay, that you've ♥♥♥♥ yourself for the first time.
But wait, there's more!
OF COURSE WE NEED A DEAD BODY TO SCREAM IN OUR EARS.
Don't play this after you've been up all night. Especially not alone
In the dark
With no sound or light, or an distraction but this.
You'll need a new wardrobe.
Now if you'll excuse me, I need to go buy some more pants.

reviewText: After playing for a mere 20 minutes it is very clear that Outlast fulfills its promise to scare. I had to turn it off and go chill out before I had a freaking heart attack. Surprisingly, the fact that there is no combat really doesn't affect the gameplay in any negative way. It is natural for a gamer to think that no combat = no real gameplay but this really isnt the case and I believe that the choice to make this non-combat is not only the correct one but THE defining factor. The mad thing is that its story is about experiments in lucid dreaming gone wrong - and that's exactly how it plays. Since you can only record events and run away - it's like a dream where you are powerless but the dream looks back at you and is not. If jump scares are your thing then forget about the other pretenders (like Five Nights at Freddies and company) and experience this lucid nightmare.\n\n*edit* Seriously do not buy it if you have a heart condition.

reviewText:
Outlast is a brilliant horror game with great scares and dark atmosphere, enough to keep you on the edge of your seat. With modern graphics and nothing but the Shift button to help you escape, it really is a game you don't want to stop playing.
Having said that, unfortunately my first run of the game took me just over 4 hours to complete without collecting the collectables, and I estimate with collecting them it would take around 6, so it's a short game but what horror game isn't these days?
Comparing to more popular Steam horror games such as Amnesia, Outlast is more visually distressing and some sights will want you asking for more.
Overall I enjoyed my experience into the groesome abandoned" asylum and it has definitely made me excited for Outlast 2.
7/10."

reviewText: Outlast is an alright" game. It is just short enough and delivers enough content to be recommended
date: but it only offers JUST enough to be recommended. With the major competition of this game being the far superior Penumbra and Amnesia games by Frictional Games it has quite a lot to live up to. Unfortunately the gameplay and "horror" are barely enough to hold the average player through. It goes for the jump scare route roughly 100% of the time. The jump scares themselves work the first and maybe the second time
recommended: but after you see it's a sub-par "one trick pony" there's no horror left in it only frustration. The enemies in this game do not follow the wonderful template set by Amnesia where they seemingly come and go as they please instead they follow a set path they patrol until you pass that area. Along with that the A.I. that they have is rather dodgy to when they actually see you and trying to hide from them can be a pain. I personally discovered that the easiest way to get past the enemy is to simply run past them the second they bust the door down instead of wasting time trying to hide. Once you run past them in most places where you have to go to make them disappear is in that room they came from. If you do try the hiding route expect to waste time dying for reasons that shouldn't happen and getting spotted in places that really don't make sense. None of that is scary. It's frustrating. A better game for jump scares is Doom 3. A better game for weaponless stealth horror would be Amnesia or Penumbra. A better game for crazy psychological/paranormal experiments is F.E.A.R. or Condemned. If it was the guts and gore that scared you even Dead Space is better for that. This game really only serves as a way to kill a few hours if you have a horror itch and have already played all of the above games. If you haven't then what are you waiting for!\n\nOverall I give it a 6/10."

reviewText: This game has all the makings of a horror game and then some. Players of both Silent Hill and Amnesia will enjoy this, as you eventually become driven to discover more about what is happening. The mechanics are polished and the graphics are decent, and the game entirely pulls you into it. Difficulty levels are varied, so if you like a game more for the story, or for its challenge, or even a mix of both, the game can provide. This game is one of the best I've played, and is more finely worked on then most of the games I've played. This game is worth your money and then some.

reviewText: There is nothing really special about this game, it doesn't add any new twists to the horror genre, or go to a type of setting you have never seen before.  But just because there is no gimmick in this game, doesn't mean it is bad.  On the contrary, this is one of the best horror games I have ever played.  The atmosphere is erie in the asylum where everything seems a little off (that may be from all the corpses and blood) and where the patients are as crazy, and deformed as it gets, and you never know how they will react.  Sometimes they just curl up in a ball and scream, and other times, they are chasing you through the sewers.  The camera that you hold to record what is happening also adds a creepy layer when you use the night vision.  The game is excellent at making tension.  There are times where you don't get attacked for twenty minutes, but you are always on alert because of the excelent sound (from the heavy breathing and heart pounding from the main character, to the sound of chains and foot steps in the distance) and the closed corridors with many doors that you don't know whats behind them.  There are also a couple good jump scares that got me, but not enough to get tire-sum or take away too much control from the organic scares that happen.  Some of the scariest parts of the game are unique to the player and not cutscenes.  For example, I was in the sewers when this big mutant who stalks you throughout the game appears.  I try to sneak past him, but he sees me and I start running.  I see a little drain hole and a quickly crawl into it.  Once Im in this cramped space, I look back to see his feet right there.  He pauses for a while before walking off.  Calmed down now, I start making my way through to the other side, when to my surprise, he had gone around and was waiting for me.  I tried to go back, but it was too late.  He dragged me out and beat me up.  It was one of the biggest jump scares for me, and it wasn't a cutscene.  They also add different scare elements and different locations (hospital, normal asylum area, office, sewers, etc) so it stays fresh, and keeps you on your toes.  The story is nothing new in the horror genre, but it isn't terrible.  The little notes that your character writes about diferent things that happen thoroughout the story, adds a bit of personality to the silent protagonist.  There were a few things that took me out of the experience though.  One was the ridiculous amount of pain the protagonist could tolerate.  He had things done to him that would normally make someone pass out, but he just grabs his camera and moves on.  Another thing that made it less scary, was when you realise how easy it is to lose someone chasing you in some cases so you don't feel the need to sneak, because there are practacally no penalties to being spotted, but this is only about halfway through.  They do a few things later in the game to freshen it up again.  To sum it up, this is a geat horror game that I would recommend to anyone who wants some thrills and solid gameplay this year.

reviewText:
Similar to the film Grave Encounters, the game is set in some kind of mental institution and you are armed with only a digital camera with a nightvision toggle that consumes the batteries. The story is told through notes you make when you have the camera out and through documents you find strewn in the levels.

It borrows from the Amnesia series in that you can't actually defend yourself against any of the unpleasant things you might encounter. Your only course of action is to run and to hide. However, whereas in Amnesia you might have had something chasing you and you knew it would kill you so you ran until you were safe with your heart pounding, in Outlast you are required to backtrack past the same enemy over and over. Far from being scary, it just becomes an annoyance.

There are many sections where you need to find a key (or other item) but when looking for it you will be seen by an enemy, then you'll run, hide in a closet, wait for him to leave, then go and search again, the same thing happens, repeat ad nausem or until he finally kills you. The scariness is gone and it just becomes frustrating. You know what you have to do; you might even know where the key is, but you have to get past something that will chase you and instantly kill you.

There is functionality to look over either shoulder using Q or E. It is not very useful though because it is disorienting. I suppose that was the intention: when running from something you take a quick glance over your shoulder and see it just behind you. The trouble is, in real life we are unaware of the movement of our head because our brain processes it for us. We don't see the world spin when we turn our head. When the game shows you everything spin it's not actually realistic, it's annoying and makes the look behind" function not very usable.

The need to use the camera with its night vision to see does add some tension
date: which is helped along by your character breathing heavily etc. There is an outdoor part which is reminiscent of The Blair Witch Project in its atomosphere.\n\nIf you like horror games then this is worth a play. It has a great atmosphere and some nice visuals. There are a few jump scares and to start with it's quite immersive until the gameplay gets a bit samey and you know what the threats are. But by that time you'll probably see it through to the end to find out what happens. The game is about the right length in that respect."

reviewText:
Well where do I even begin...

The game immediately sets the tone to be epically scary by only allowing you the ability to run, hide, and record on a camcorder. The camcorder has a nightvision feature that drains the battery as it is being used. This made for a quite exciting and high suspense game as you are sometimes racing to find a battery before you are left in the dark with all the bad things you don't want!

The game wasn't extremely long, and compared to Dead Space, the death scenes were still good, just not Dead Space good haha which is ok because this is Outlast. I wish they had more variety for the death scenes (multiple per enemy). Either way. FANTASTIC game.... my stomach was in my chest the whole time.

I LEGIT jumped AND screamed in this game, I am a 27 year old man who LOVES horror and doesn't startle that easily. The tone the game sets is just perfect enough to suck you close to the screen before it unleashes horror and terror on your vulnerable mind! Definitely a screwed up story, and some controversial religious topics to anyone who is offended by blasphemy. Very graphic, lots of gore, and NOT for the faint of heart.

I would rate the game an 8/10

Fantastic game worth every penny (though is was gifted to me by a stream viewer, I feel I would of not been upset and feel it was money well spent!!)

A mixed bag of thrill, boredom, excitement, reiteration and different shades of fear, with a nice mocumentary look & feel. This game truly packs their share of jumpscares throughout the game, and yes, it did manage to scare me often. The ambience is truly amazing and greatly fits and improves to horror scenes. And the soundtrack is good. ( In my opinion ) The game's conflicts however, seem to be a bit repetitive, usually requiring you to activate certain pumps/engines while avioding one of the games enemies who walks around looking for you. The game story overall is good, and has their share of plot twists.

The graphics are highly detailed and realistic, matching the overall scene of Mount Massive Asylum very well. The asylum looks truly realistic, and I can't help being sucked into the game every once in a while.

The only negative thing I would have to say about this game is its repetivity, like I recently stated, this game constantly requires you to keep activating engines and stuff, while evading the boss. You  can try rushing along, or you could use stealth, which involves alot of waiting for the right moment and eventually getting seen and running back.

The game really fits as a survival horror, having only few fight" scenes
date: one being when Dr.Trager last tries to kill you in the elevator.\n\nOverall
recommended:
I would recommend this as a good horror game full of exciting ( and scary ) adventure.

8/10


If you're into horror games

reviewText: My favourite horror game along with Amnesia: The Dark Descent. Though I think this one's better for simple reason. The gameplay is really simple. Playing it with your headphones at night can be scary (not to say terrifying). A good game for its price, I maybe enjoyed it more than I should have, but I truly recommend you to play it.

reviewText: It's a game about chasers not able to turn a pommel, bad guys always looking in the locker beside the one you are hidden in and floppy ♥♥♥♥♥ thrown on your face, with a structure often so linear and coercive that seems to want to make trial and error a new religion. But it's also a game that knows how to nail his concept, making you truly feel hunted, desperately running for your life, with the heart in your throat, in the middle of a obscure and febrile nightmare. A mixed bag of thrill, boredom, excitement, reiteration and different shades of fear, with a nice mocumentary look & feel. It can be a good companion for a couple of sleepless nights, if bought during a sale.

reviewText: A game where the threat of a scare is more powerful than the scare itself. The game consists moslty of jumpscares, but these are well done and, for the most part, unexpected. Things you expect to come alive and jump at you, never do. And situations that seem safe (compared to others) turn out to be the most disturbing and stomach turning scares Ive ever seen. Adding on to this, the feeling of being 100% helpless has a huge impact and at times found my self panicking along with my character as I scramble in the dark trying to find something to hide in or under. All and all, this game has taken at least a year off of my life. And my heart still has yet to return to a normal pace, though this may be influenced by fatty foods. I highly recommend.

reviewText: If you're coming off the disappointment of Amnesia: March of the Pigs (not to be confused with the brilliance of Amnesia: The Dark Descent), look no further for legitimate mood and tone. Feel the of breath in the pitch black of enemies bearing down on you; someone or something constantly pursing you... to which you are unarmed and you're only defense is the black of night and your ability to hide. Outlast does everything great that Amnesia does, only to a much more frantic and chilling setting. Yes there are jump scares, but they are scarce and cleverly placed. Outlast is a true horror experience.

reviewText:
Actually this game was quite funny, featuring a cool, interesting story. Sadly the gameplay wasnt that great; the controls felt weird especially when jumping (I fell down a dozen times in the female ward chpt) and it turned out to be a little hard to figure out the position of enemy movement. Many things don't make any sense either, like the AI (not too bright), battery life or where enemies actually come from. You do not have to hide, I even managed to simply run until they stopped following me. There are no puzzles. Plus, the game isn't scary.. like .. at all. For my sense of humor it was more like a fun ride - tons of organs+body parts (lavvl), funny (&&stereotypical) characters and notes (with lots of spelling mistakes in the german version).
This may be a good choice for you if you're scared of ... let's say the darkness(nyctophobia) or nosocomephobia - cause I don't think normal ppl will find this scary. (maybe you don't want it to be..)

Played on 'nightmare' difficulty, since I wanted to have savegames.. .

reviewText:
The best horror game I have ever played, hands down! Outlast is riveting from start to finish, full of real scares. The game doesn't rely on pop up scares that are unexpected and make you jump (although it has them!) But rather relies on full tension having you walk around knowing something is about to happen, creating anxiety for when it does actualy happen. Some parts I literaly had to stop and have a break as my heart was pounding and my hands were sweating so much I felt I couldn't go on :)

Really clever level design, it felt very original and authentic. And the music/soundtrack added to the tension and even created some of it. The A.I. also was brilliant!

The best horror experience I've ever had, and one of the best games I've ever played!!
Bring on The Whistleblower DLC!

10/10.

reviewText:
This was probably the most fun I've had playing a horror game in a good while. I do not usually pick up or buy horror based games (nor do I see horror movies). However, I received this game as a gift from a friend during the Winter Holidays.

This game was really well done. The graphic and shadowing made it realisited as you made your way through the Asylum on Mount Massive. Having to depend solely on your ability to hide, sneak, RUN, to get through the treacherous place and maze of corridor made the game tough and enjoyable.

The best part in my opinion was the camera. Having to rely on it throughout most of the game. (well essentially all except a small bit). But it made you think about when you should use it and when you shouldnt. Especially since batteries that powered was your lifeline and you never know when you may need the camera (and if you had no batteries left...damn that blows).

I played this game over two nights with friends who watched the twitch and spent the time chatting and commenting on the game and what was happening (whether complaining at my inability to jump or my inability to play different voices of the letters out loud). We had a blast.

I highly recommend this game. The whol survive as things go bump in the night was a lot of fun. The best part of the game is the cracked camera. The thought and cleverness of the developers/designer to do that as you traveled. This made it very realistic since a camera does get beat up like the character.

The whole story puts you wondering the asylum and you start to care about your character. Feeling bad he falls when you jump or when he gets caught and killed. You go through so much in this game that you become connected, he goes through so much in this game that it makes it all the more motivating to keep going and see what happens next.

I recommend playnig this game.

reviewText:
DISCLAIMER: This reviewer has not played the Whistleblower DLC and therefore, their rating and comments on the game will not be accounting for this content. This review will contain no spoilers for neither plot nor story.

-TRIAL AND ERROR SIMULATOR

If you buy this game, prepare for sub-par gameplay. You have little  to no influence over whether you survive an enemy encounter or not - as aforementioned, in obnoxious CapsLock, when you encounter an enemy, all you can do is run away  - which is all well and good, right? Many games

Because of three major points
column22: easily compensates for the aforementioned flaws:\n\n1) The plot: Many Horror games
column23: and especially movies for that matter
column24: have an incredibly dull and boring plot
column25: and only get small points for cheap jump scares and similar tropes. This game is not one of those. At all. While there certainly are jump scares
column26: the plot of this story is easily one of the most interesting
column27: fascinating and most well-fleshed out ones I've experienced in any Horror game
column28: being up there with classic Silent Hill
column29: classic Resident Evil and the first Amnesia (note that I'm not comparing this plot to those games
column30: it is in no way similar
column31: it just delivers the same amount of quality). It puts you in the setting
column32: ranging from fairly peaceful-looking to fishy to "what the ♥♥♥♥ is going on?" to batshit insanity. And it does so in a very smooth way
column33: with no try-hard scares and forced plotting like you occasionally see in other games of the genre.\n\n2) The design: This is mainly focused on characters - both their aesthetic appearance and their personality. You are presented with a wide array of interesting characters
column34: all done in a way where you're never quite sure whom to trust and whom to oppose. You're going to be falling through the cracks attempting to figure out who is good and who is bad - in other words
column35: the characters are what presents this great plot in its own way: a complete and utter moral greyzone.\n\n3) The atmosphere: The story unfolds in an old mental hospital
column36: and you might think it's cliché
column37: that you've seen this all before
column38: that it is an overused setting. And you might be right - but assuredly
column39: it has never been presented in the way Outlast manages to: grim darkness in every corner
column40: the palette of clinical instruments and brushed steel paired with horrible gore and bloodstains
column41: spiced with deranged freaks walking around everywhere
column43: makes the raw experience of this game easily worth both your time and your money.\n\nOverall
column44: I would certainly recommend this game - if you manage to read this review while there's a sale
column45: there is ABSOLUTELY NO EXCUSE not to buy this game if you're a die-hard Horror fanatic like me
column46: and you've got money in your pocket. And don't worry about my initial remarks about the gameplay: they're effortlessly overshadowed by the great story

reviewText: This is the kind of game you will get a love/hate relationship with. In my opinion it might be the best horror game I have ever played. If you like horror games, you will probably love Outlast. (Particularly if you like to be trapped inside an asylum where something has gone very very wrong and the most of the people you meet will be dead people and/or people you wish would be dead, or at least not there to chase you and kill you. Oh, and also - You can't defend youself. Just run and hope that you wlll not run out of batteries for the nightvision of your camera.) This game will probably scare the living crap out of you. It's brilliantly horribly scary and disturbing and Red Barrels have done such a fantastic job, especially considering it's such a small indie game studio.

reviewText: Took about 6-ish hours to beat the entire game. This game is definitely very spooky, and doesn't abuse jump scares (abusing jump scares is a sin for horror games in my opinion). It does get kind of repetitive, but still manages to keep you hooked. I definitely recommend it, especially if it is on sale.
